My God, how many are my fears!  
They echo in the hollow rooms of night,  
Like bells that toll for ancient, buried years,  
Their trembling shadows veiling out the light.  
A thousand trembling hands upon my chest,  
Invisible but real as winter’s breath,  
They press and twist and grant me no soft rest,  
Each one a whisper prophesying death.  
Yet in this throng of specters, I remain—  
A watcher at the window, counting dreams,  
And though the storm may rattle on the pane,  
A quiet hope will rise between the seams.  
For fears may multiply, but so does grace,  
And dawn will find me in a gentler place.

My God, how many are my fears!  
They gather like crows at dusk,  
A black-winged parliament on the wires,  
Cawing doubts until hope is but a husk.  
They perch on my shoulders, whispering lies,  
Tallying every misstep and sorrow;  
With every heartbeat, another one flies  
In, promising darkness tomorrow.  
Yet even as terror multiplies,  
A stubborn ember glows deep in my chest—  
A secret defiance that quietly defies  
The endless parade of unrest.  
So let the fears come, I'll name them each one,

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You burst through curtains, day begun—
Blundering in on secret hours,
Unheeding of our sleepy powers.
Why must you rouse the morning air?
Why scatter dreams and lay us bare?
Your golden fingers prod and pry,
Ignoring lovers' soft goodbye.
Not all must wake, nor all rejoice
At your brash, uninvited voice.
Yet, in your glare, all things are spun:
The world awakes, the night is done.
So though you scold with every ray,
We rise, unwilling, to the day.

Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air—
I wander through the liquid light,
Where shadows scatter, feather-thin,
And morning’s hush dispels the night.

A heron lifts from mirrored reeds,
Ripples folding, soft and clear.
The world, unhurried, softly breathes—
Newborn, trembling, free from fear.

With every step, the grass recalls
The secrets of a silver dawn.
I gather silence as it falls,
And wear its peace the whole day long.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not gold, nor words, nor woven spell,
But maybe echoes in the hall,
A shadow’s murmur through the wall.
A garden wild with tangled green,
A page half-read, a dream unseen.
What I shall leave: a broken clock,
A songbird startled from the flock.

No legacy in marble cast,
No portrait meant to ever last.
Instead, a glance, a breath, a trace—
The memory of a fleeting face.
So take this silence as my gift,
A hush between the world’s great shift,
And wonder, as the years compel:
What I shall leave thee—none can tell.

O blustering tyrant, gaudy king of dawn,
Your golden fingers claw the curtains thin,
Dragging dreams away before they’re gone,
And rousing lovers who would sleep within.
How many worlds must yawn beneath your gaze,
Their secret hopes unspooled before your eyes?
You scold the moon and banish gentle haze,
Yet never ask the weary if they rise.
Bright busybody, uninvited guest,
Who hurries time and frets the silent hours,
We beg you, let us linger, let us rest,
For hearts are not remade by all your powers.
Cease your relentless, meddlesome parade—
Let shadows stay, let longing never fade.

What I shall leave thee none can tell—
A fragment of dawn in a wishing well,
The hush of footsteps on dew-wet stone,
A melody hummed when you’re alone.

Perhaps a spark in a winter’s breeze,
Or petals pressed in secret diaries.
A riddle folded within a dream,
The glint of hope in a silver seam.

Beyond the tangible, past the known,
My parting gift is rarely shown.
Hold close the silence where I fell—
What I shall leave thee, none can tell.

Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air—
A silent hush, the world prepares.
Grass blades shimmer, dew jewels bright,
Gentle hush before the light.

The sleeping hills in silver dressed,
Birdsong stirs from feathered rest.
Inhale promise, pure and rare—
The day is born in crisp, cold air.

Each breath a hope, each step a prayer,
Among the shadows softly there.
Beneath the mist, before the sun,
A world begun, a race unrun.

Imprinted like stars in our skies.

No matter how fleeting the glance,
For each is a stitch in your tapestry,

It finally snapped! The world recoiled,
As if a violin string had broken in the midst of a symphony—
A sudden, sharp silence where music once threaded the air.
Somewhere, a spider’s web surrendered to the wind,
Letting go of its delicate latticework with grace.
What held us together—those thin, invisible fibers—
Could not bear the weight of one more day, one more sigh.
Yet in the aftermath, the dusk shimmered with possibility.
Not all ruptures are rifts; some are openings,
A chance for the hush to speak, for new notes to begin.
It finally snapped: and from the fracture, a strange freedom flowed.

Listen, and gather these treasures so small—

Within the shadowed camps by Scamander’s flow,
Patroclus dons the armor, his eyes aglow,
Sixteen through nineteen, the epic unfurls—
Fates entwined in the dust, gods’ thunderous hurls.

Myrmidons rally, their leader in bronze,
A borrowed fury, as destiny dawns.
Hector awaits at the gates of the doomed,
While horses of Achilles sense what’s been gloomed.

Sarpedon falls where the wild spears meet,
And Zeus weighs his soul, bitterly replete.
Patroclus, emboldened, drives Troy to its knees,
But pride is Achilles’, and death rides the breeze.

Sable night gathers as armor rings red,
A hero’s demise, a promise unsaid.
Mourning and fury: the gods turn their face—
Books sixteen to nineteen, fate’s cruel embrace.

From the smoky hollows of battle-torn Troy,
Books sixteen through nineteen recount hope and destroy.
Patroclus, in armor, with borrowed resolve,
Spurs the Myrmidons forth, as old debts evolve.

Zeus weighs the fates, as Sarpedon falls low,
Gods meddle and mourn, their anger on show.
Hector, emboldened, stalks over the field,
While Achilles’ absence leaves wounds unhealed.

Fury rides chariots, steeds foam at the bit,
The river runs red where the fallen men sit.
Grief, like a specter, hovers by shield and by spear—
In these books, the heart of the Iliad beats clear.

O Homer, your verses hold rage and regret;
In the tale of Patroclus, we never forget.

Birds told the sky all their jubilant tales;
By dusk, all my questions were quietly gone.

Today was the day everything went on its way—
And I, in the middle, just let myself sway.

How can you grieve and express loss?
By folding the quiet into the corners of each day,
By letting the ache bleed into the color of sunrise.
You might whisper their name into the echo of dusk,
Or place a hand on the dent in the pillow they left behind.
There are the letters never sent, the songs never sung—
Let them tumble from your heart, raw and unrefined.
Loss is the shape of an absence in a crowded room,
A laugh remembered, a scent on old fabric.
Grieve in the language only you can speak:
A sigh, a sketch, a single white stone on a path.
And know that to express loss is not to let go,
But to carry the memory—fragile, luminous—
Into each new moment, until sorrow softens into love.

Grieve as the rain grieves for the sky it must leave,

To grieve is to testify: I loved, I remember, I remain.

I always see to it—the hinges oiled, the windows gleaming,
No shadow left unattended, no silent, hidden dreaming.
I sweep the dust of yesterday from corners of my mind,
And polish every memory, the bitter and the kind.

I always see to it—the clock’s persistent ticking,
The way the world keeps turning, the way my heart keeps picking
Through tangled weeds and worries, through hope that sometimes fades,
I always see to it—that the light is never shade.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

instance_metrics.response:
I always see to it—the lock turned just so,  
The notes in a notebook where secrets don’t go.  
I plant tiny saplings that no one will know,  
And whisper to petals that shiver in snow.  
  
A watcher of thresholds, a mender of seams,  
I cradle the silence that pulses in dreams.  
With hands that remember and eyes that believe,  
I always see to it—what’s woven won’t leave.  
  
There’s care in the corners, there’s light in the gloom,  
I always see to it—there’s hope left in bloom.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

instance_metrics.response:
I always see to it—tasks lined up like dominoes,  
Falling one by one, a careful, quiet prose.  
The sink, the song, the midday sun,  
The small undone that must be done.  
  
I always see to it—the kettle’s hiss, the folded sheet,  
The promise kept that no one greets.  
Invisible, persistent, the steely thread—  
I always see to it, though nothing’s said.  
  
A silent steward of the hours,  
I always see to it: these daily flowers.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

instance_metrics.response:
I always see to it—the moon’s arc in the ink-black sea,
That the lantern in the attic flickers faithfully for me.
I sweep the attic’s cobwebbed hush, collecting time’s debris,
Unspooling all the silver threads of memory’s debris.

I always see to it—letters stamped and never sent,
The shoes lined in the hallway, each footprint’s faint intent.
I tend the steady rituals, the ones that go unseen—
A guardian of the thresholds that flicker in between.

So I stitch the quiet minutes, mend the spaces in the air,
I always see to it—somebody, somewhere, cares.

instance_metrics.response:
Now when I have a cold,
The world recedes in mist and wool,
Each breath a waltz with winter air,
The kettle hums a muted lull,
My voice, now cracked, is someone else’s song.
Between the blankets' gentle siege,
I count the patterns on the wall,
Discovering continents in tissue maps—
Each sneeze a distant thunderclap,
And tea the only ship that sails my sea.
Outside, the world keeps spinning,
But here, within this fevered dusk,
The cold is not a foe but quiet friend,
Reminding me to rest, to mend,
To listen close to small, forgotten things.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

instance_metrics.response:
Now when I have a cold,
I find the world is distant, blurred,
A hush of rain against the glass,
A clock whose hands move slow, unheard.
The taste of lemons, honey, thyme—
Cascade in waves upon my tongue,
And every exhalation climbs
Like smoke from incense, pale and young.
My body drifts, a paper boat,
On rivers made of ginger tea,
And every ache becomes a note
In an aching, soft symphony.
Now when I have a cold, I dream—
Wrapped safe in fog, adrift in steam.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

instance_metrics.response:
Now when I have a cold,
My senses dwindle, sharpness dulls;
The world in muffled tones unfolds,
A distant bell, a faded pulse.
Beneath my quilted mountain range,
I drift between the near and far,
Window-ghosts on windowpanes,
And tea that steams like morning stars.
The hours blur in fevered gray,
My thoughts like snowflakes, slow and small,
Yet in this hush, I find a way
To cradle silence, heed the fall
Of every breath, of every sigh—
Now when I have a cold, I lie
Inside a gentler, softer sky.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

instance_metrics.response:
Now when I have a cold,
I nestle in the smallest nook,
A fortress built of pillows, old
dog-eared books and woolen looks.
The rain outside seems far away,
Its tapping lost to cotton ears;
Inside, the world turns softer gray,
Familiar voices disappear.
Soup simmers in a distant room
And time unspools without a care.
I watch the shadowed afternoon
And breathe the gentle, stuffy air.
Now when I have a cold, I find
A quiet peace within my mind.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

instance_metrics.response: Now when I have a cold, I become a slow-ticking clock, uncoiling minutes like woolen scarves. My thoughts curl up, drowsy cats around the radiator, and the world’s sharp edges soften in the haze. I am an island adrift in a sea of tissues, my only visitors the steam rising from my mug and the shadows dancing on the ceiling. Each cough is an echo down a hallway I no longer roam; each sneeze a sudden thunderclap in the hush. The outside world is urgent, brisk, but within these sickroom walls, time is syrup-thick and kindness reigns—a gentle hand on my brow, a lullaby at noon. Now when I have a cold, I remember how quietly a body can heal, how sweet it is to be still.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

instance_metrics.response:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With nimble fingers, robbed the golden days?
He steals in silence, veiled in gentle truth,
And leaves behind a hush where laughter plays.

In mirrors now I glimpse his shadowed art,
A silver wisp upon my brow’s domain.
He threads his secrets deep within my heart,
As petals fall and memories remain.

Yet though he plunders hours from my grasp,
He cannot dim the fire that hope ignites.
For every fleeting moment I unclasp,
New wisdom dawns and sorrow yields to light.

So let him take what time decrees to claim—
My soul grows brighter, though my skin be tame.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

instance_metrics.response:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept in on silent feet, with gentle guile,
And plucked the blooming rose before its truth
Could fully open, radiant for a while.

I chase the echoes of a distant spring,
A laughter lost in corridors of gray;
His shadow stretches, thin and whispering,
Across the golden fields I once called May.

Yet in each wrinkle, wisdom finds its place,
The lines a testament to journeys made;
Though Time may brush his hand upon my face,
He cannot steal the dreams that never fade.

So let him take the hours, swift and fleet—
The heart remembers what the years delete.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

instance_metrics.response:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Has tiptoed past the guardians of my days.
He pilfers gentle laughter, seeds of truth,
And leaves behind the hush of ashen grays.

No lock nor plea can halt his quiet hand;
He weaves the dusk through what was bright and green.
Yet in the shadows, memories still stand—
Old echoes haunting places I have been.

Though Time may snatch the luster from my hair,
And etch his stories deep into my skin,
He cannot touch the wonder kindled there,
Nor steal the spark that burns and glows within.

So let him pass, that artful, furtive guest—
For in my heart’s own garden, youth will rest.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

instance_metrics.response:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Unspools the golden hours with silent care.
He treads the path where dreams once soared in truth,
And leaves behind a sigh upon the air.

A fleeting glance—a shadow on the wall—
Reminds me of the laughter left behind.
He gently dims the voices that recall
The fearless songs that danced within my mind.

Yet as he gathers what I cannot keep,
He sows within my soul a deeper light.
In wisdom’s arms, I cradle what I reap;
The dusk reveals new colors in the night.

Though Time will claim each blossom in his flight,
He grants the root a strength to hold the light.

instance_metrics.response:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Unravels silken threads from memory’s loom.
Within his satchel, laughter’s fragile truth
Is folded tight, entombed in silent gloom.

The orchard’s blush, the reckless, golden noon—
He gathers all with hands both swift and sly.
A watchful crow, he croaks another tune
To mark the bright illusions passing by.

Yet in the vault where stolen summers sleep,
I find strange treasures, burnished not decayed:
A stubborn hope, a promise meant to keep—
A light that, though diminished, will not fade.

So let Time take the bounty of my spring—
The winter’s wisdom is its offering.
